verses.verse: ((5 Elihu chargeth Job, that he called himself righteous.12 He showeth that God is just in his judgments.24 God destroyeth the mighty.30 By him the hypocrite reigneth.) ) Moreover Elihu answered and said,
Hear my words, ye (Which are esteemed wise of the world.) wise men, and hearken unto me ye that have knowledge.
For the ear trieth the words, as the mouth tasteth meat.
Let us seek (Let us examine the matter uprightly.) judgment among us, and let us know among ourselves what is good.
For Job hath said, I am righteous, and God hath taken (That is, hath afflicted me without measure.) away my judgment.
Should I lie in my (Should I say, I am wicked, being an innocent?) right? my wound of the arrow is (I am sorer punished, than my sin deserveth.) grievous without my sin.
What man is like Job, that drinketh (Which is compelled to receive thy reproach and scorns of many for his foolish words.) scornfulness like water?

Which goeth in the (Meaning, that Job was like to the wicked, because he seemed not to glorify God and submit himself to his judgments.) company of them that work iniquity, and walketh with wicked men?

For he hath said, It (He wresteth Job’s words who said that God’s children are ofttimes punished in this world, and the wicked go free.) profiteth a man nothing that he should (That is, live godly, as Gen. 5:22.) walk with God.
Therefore hearken unto me, ye men of wisdom, God forbid that wickedness should be in God, and iniquity in the Almighty.
For he will render unto man according to his work, and cause everyone to find according to his way.
And certainly God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert judgment.
Whom (Cross references: : Job 26:23) hath he appointed over the earth besides himself? or who hath placed the whole world?
If (To destroy him.) he set his heart upon man, and gather unto himself his spirit (The breath of life which he gave man.) and his breath,
All flesh shall perish together, and man shall return unto dust.
And if thou hast understanding, hear this, and hearken to the voice of my words.
Shall he that hateth judgment, (If God were not just, how could he govern the world?) govern? and wilt thou judge him wicked that is most just?
Wilt thou say unto a king, Thou art (If man of nature fear to speak evil of such as have power, then much more ought they to be afraid to speak evil of God.) wicked? or to princes, Ye are ungodly?
How much less to him that accepteth not the persons of princes, and regardeth not the rich, more than the poor? for they be all the work of his hands.

They shall die suddenly, (When they look not for it.) and the people shall be troubled at midnight, (The messengers of visitation that God shall send.) and they shall pass forth and take away the mighty without hand.
For his eyes are upon the ways of man, and he seeth all his goings.
There is no darkness nor shadow of death, that the workers of iniquity might be hid therein.
For he will not lay on man so much, that he should (God doth not afflict man above measure, so that he should have occasion to contend with him.) enter into judgment with God.
He shall break the mighty without (For all his creatures are at hand to serve him, so that he needeth not to seek for any other army.) seeking, and shall set up others in their stead.
Therefore shall he declare their (Make them manifest that they are wicked.) works: he shall turn the (Declare the things that were hid.) night, and they shall be destroyed.
He striketh them as wicked men in the places of the (Meaning, openly in the sight of all men.) seers,
Because they have turned back from him, and would not consider all his ways:
So that they have caused the voice of the poor to (By their cruelty and extortion.) come unto him, and he hath heard the cry of the afflicted.
And when he giveth quietness, who can make trouble? and when he hideth his face, who can behold him, whether it be upon nations, or upon a man only?

Because the (When tyrants sit in the throne of justice which under pretence of executing justice are but hypocrites and oppress the people, it is a sign that God hath drawn back his countenance of favor from that place.) hypocrite doth reign, and because the people are snared.
Surely it appertaineth unto God (Only it belongeth to God to moderate his corrections, and not unto man.) to say, I have pardoned, I will not destroy.
(Thus Elihu speaketh in the person of God, as it were mocking Job, because he would be wiser than God.) But if I see not, teach thou me: if I have done wickedly, I will do no more.

Will he perform the thing through (Will God use thy counsel in doing his works?) thee? for thou hast reproved (Thus he speaketh in the person of God, as though Job should choose and refuse affliction at his pleasure.) it, because that thou hast chosen, and not I: now speak what thou knowest.
Let men of understanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken unto me.
Job hath not spoken of knowledge, neither were his words according to wisdom.
I desire that Job may be (That he may speak as much as he can, that we may answer him and all the wicked that shall use such arguments.) tried, unto the end, touching the answers for wicked men.
For he (He standeth stubbornly in the maintenance of his cause.) addeth rebellion unto his sin, he clappeth his hands among us, and multiplieth his words against God.
